properties.areaDesc: Pickens, SC; Oconee, SC; Anderson, SC
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 3 at 2:00PM EST until January 3 at 5:45PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
* At 155 PM EST, Doppler radar indicates the earlier heavy rainfall
has ended across Anderson, Oconee, and Pickens counties; however, an
area of 1-3 inches of rainfall occurred between approximately 9:30am
and noon, causing flooding of low-lying areas and roadways.

* Several reports of flooded roads have been received by local media
and law enforcement, especially in the urban centers of Central,
Clemson, Easley, and Pendleton.  These roads include: Grant Street
in Easley, Central Road in Pendleton, Isaqueena Trail and Berkeley
Road in Clemson, and Pinedale Road in Central.  Roadway flooding
of less than 12" depth may continue for a few more hours as runoff
continues to work through area streams.  It is important to
continue to heed all barricades and seek an alternative route.

* Area streams continue to rise, though cresting should be imminent
for most streams.  Nevertheless, additional flooding adjacent to
streams is likely over the next few hours as it takes a while for
excessive runoff to work through the soils and into adjacent
streams.  Therefore, avoid streams and adjacent areas through the
afternoon.

* The following streamgauge is exceeding Action/Advisory Stage:
Eighteenmile Creek at SC 28 in Pendleton.

Current Stage: 10.49 feet and rising slowly.
Forecast: Eighteenmile Creeek will continue to rise to near
11 feet before cresting.
Action Stage: 10.5 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 6.0 feet.
Impacts: At 11.0 feet the creek will be flooding low-lying areas
adjacent to SC 28 and flooding of Bishop Branch Rd. and Central Rd.
is likely.

* Some locations that will continue to experience flooding include...
Easley, Clemson, Seneca, Powdersville, Piedmont, Central,
Pendleton, Liberty, Norris and Townville.

* Additional heavy rainfall is possible this afternoon and evening.
Given the very wet antecedent conditions, any additional heavy
rainfall may prompt new rounds of flooding.  Please stay weather
aware.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Heavy rainfall is causing significant ponding of water in urban
areas, streets and underpasses, as well as other poor drainage areas
and low lying spots. Rapid rises on small creeks and streams is
occurring, possibly flooding low-water crossings and farmland. Do
not attempt to travel across flooded roads.

NWSheadline: THE FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 545 PM EST FOR NORTHERN ANDERSON...CENTRAL PICKENS AND SOUTHEASTERN OCONEE COUNTIES
